title: 111_hr2667
content: The "Early Support for Families Act" is a legislation that provides grants to states for quality home visitation programs for families with young children and families expecting children. This Act aims to support quality home visitation programs for these families. The purpose of this section is to improve the well-being of children by establishing quality home visitation programs for families with young children and expecting families. States must submit a grant application describing the programs, intended outcomes, and evidence of effectiveness. The grant made to the State under this section will support families with young children and expecting families. A statewide needs assessment will provide information on the number and quality of home visitation programs, eligible families receiving services, funding sources, and gaps in early childhood home visitation. The State must provide assurances that it will prioritize serving communities in high need of home visitation services, especially those with a high proportion of low-income families or child maltreatment. Funding sources, gaps in early childhood home visitation, and training activities to support program goals must also be reported. The State must prioritize serving communities with high need for home visitation services, particularly those with a high proportion of low-income families or child maltreatment. 5% of grant funds will be reserved for training and technical assistance. Coordination with other child and family services, health services, and income supports will be promoted. Referrals to other programs will be provided when appropriate. The State must prioritize serving communities with high need for home visitation services, particularly those with a high proportion of low-income families or child maltreatment. 5% of grant funds will be reserved for training and technical assistance. Coordination with other child and family services, health services, and income supports will be promoted. Referrals to other programs will be provided when appropriate. The Secretary may require additional information. Allotments to Indian tribes will be based on the number of children in the tribe whose families have income. The Secretary will allot funds to Indian tribes and States based on the number of children in low-income families. States must prioritize serving communities with high need for home visitation services, and 5% of grant funds will be reserved for training and technical assistance. Coordination with other child and family services will be promoted. The Secretary will allot funds to States based on the number of children in low-income families. States must certify the expenditure of funds, with any unspent amounts available for reallotment. The State certifies funds not used will be reallotted. States must maintain expenditure levels for home visitation programs. The Secretary will grant funds to States meeting requirements. The Secretary will make a grant to States meeting requirements for home visitation programs, based on eligible expenditures and allotted funds. The reimbursable percentage varies by fiscal year. The term 'reimbursable percentage' varies by fiscal year: 85% for 2010, 80% for 2011, and 75% for 2012 onwards. Eligible expenditures refer to providing voluntary home visitation for families with young children through evidence-based models. The program must adhere to evidence-based home visitation models that have shown positive effects on child and parenting outcomes, employ well-trained staff, and establish linkages to community resources. The program must adhere to evidence-based home visitation models with strong organizational capacity, appropriate linkages to community resources, and include expenditures for training and evaluations. Priority funding is given to programs with the strongest evidence of effectiveness. Expenditures for programs not following evidence-based home visitation models are not eligible if they exceed a certain percentage of the State's allotment for the fiscal year. The applicable percentage varies each fiscal year, starting at 60% in 2010 and decreasing annually. The State's allotment for home visitation programs must meet specific percentage requirements each fiscal year, starting at 60% in 2010 and decreasing annually. States cannot use other federal funds to cover their share of costs, and the Secretary has the authority to waive certain provisions for Indian tribes if necessary. The State must submit annual reports on the progress of grant-funded programs under this section. Indian tribes can have provisions waived or modified by the Secretary if it imposes an undue burden. The State must submit annual reports on the progress of grant-funded programs under this section, detailing services, program characteristics, provider qualifications, recipient demographics, and program costs. The evaluation of home visitation programs includes assessing the number of recipients, their demographics, family retention, program costs, outcomes for recipients, training provided, and monitoring methods. An independent evaluation of program effectiveness is conducted by the Secretary through grants or contracts. The Secretary conducts an independent evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section to assess their impact on child and parent outcomes, including child maltreatment, health, development, and school readiness. The evaluation also examines the effectiveness of these programs on different populations. The Secretary conducts an evaluation of home visitation programs funded under this section to assess their impact on child and parent outcomes. Reports to Congress are required within 2 years for an interim report and within 4 years for a final report. Additionally, annual reports on program activities are to be submitted to Congress. The Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress on the activities funded under this section, including details on targeted high need communities, service delivery models, program characteristics such as staff qualifications and recipient demographics. The Secretary must submit annual reports to Congress on the activities funded under this section, including details on recipient characteristics, program outcomes, research-based instruction, training activities, costs, and monitoring methods used by States. The Secretary reserves funds for program evaluation, training, and technical assistance, including grants to Indian tribes. $10,000,000 is allocated for evaluation and training, with an additional 3% of the total appropriation for tribal grants. $100,000,000 is appropriated for fiscal year 2010. The Secretary is appropriated funds for fiscal years 2010 to 2014, totaling $100,000,000 for 2010, $250,000,000 for 2011, $400,000,000 for 2012, $550,000,000 for 2013, and $700,000,000 for 2014. Indian tribes are treated as states in this section.
